titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Yale University School of Medicine Miscellaneous Papers
Yale University School of Medicine Miscellaneous Papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid by Toby A. Appel based on the materials and previous finding aids by Zara Jones Powers (1959) and Stephen Yearl (as Medical Library Student Assistant).

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 03:00

did.unittitle: Yale University School of Medicine Miscellaneous Papers.

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

did.abstract: The collection contains papers of the Medical Institution of Yale College (Yale University School of Medicine) including correspondence, committee reports, financial reports, and memorials to the Yale Corporation, especially during the period when Charles A Linsdley served as Dean (1863-1885).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred to the Medical Historical Library by the Beinecke Library in 1977. Previously the collection had been on long term loan to the Historical Library, since 1961, from the former Rare Book Room at Sterling Memorial Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Yale University School of Medicine Miscellaneous Papers, Historical Library, Cushing/Whitney Medical LIbrary, Yale University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first series consists predominantly of incoming correspondence to the Dean of the Medical Institution of Yale College (Yale University School of Medicine), the President of Yale College (Jeremiah Day, Theodore Woolsey, Noah Porter), or the Secretary of Yale College (Franklin B. Dexter). Included are responses to offers of chairs and letters of resignation of chairs. Also, there are a number of letters from graduates of the school who have not yet paid their fees. The second series contains reports of the joint committees of representatives of Yale and the Connecticut Medical Society for nominating professors and for examining candidates for the M.D.; various petitions from students to the medical school; correspondence and memorials from the Dean or medical faculty or committees of the medical faculty to the President and the Yale Corporation; and financial reports of the medical school and requests for appropriations. A number of papers document the medical school's unique relationship with the Connecticut Medical Society and its dissolution in 1879-1884; the school's reorganization as the Medical Department of Yale College in 1879; the School's agreement with the New Haven Dispensary to use its facilities for clinical teaching; and the serious financial problems of the school. Of special note are several early letters related to the organization of the Medical School in 1810-1812, including three letters from Benjamin Silliman to Jonathan Knight (Jr.) in 1812, two letters from Jonathan Knight, Sr. to Jonathan Knight in 1812, and a letter in 1810 from Timothy Gridley to Jonathan Knight, Sr. on recruiting Nathan Smith. The bulk of this collection dates from the deanship of Charles Augustus Lindsley (1863-1885).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Medical Institution of Yale College was chartered by the Connecticut Legislature in 1810 as a joint project of Yale College and the Connecticut Medical Society. The Society, which had the state's power to set standards and to license candidates for medical practice, agreed to require a year of attendance at Yale or similar medical college in addition to an apprenticeship in order for a candidate to be licensed. Two years attendance were required for an M.D. In return, the representatives of the Society participated jointly with representatives of Yale in nominating professors for vacancies and in examining candidates for the license and the M.D. Leading members of the Medcial Society were invited to address the graduates at the commencement ceremony each year. Also, each county medical society could nominate a student for a free course of lectures for a year. The Medical Institution opened in 1813. with four teaching faculty: Nathan Smith, Benjamin Sillliman, Eli Ives, and Jonathan Knight. Students paid each professor directly for each course. In the period of the deanship of Charles Augustus Lindsley, this system underwent major changes. In 1875, the Medical Institution offered a three year graded course, but because of the agreement with the Connecticut Medical Society, the three years could not yet be required for an M.D. In two stages, 1879 and 1884, the agreement between the Society and Yale was dissolved, ending participation of the Society members on committees and allowing Yale to require the three-year course to obtain an M.D. In 1879, the medical school made an agreement to use the New Haven Dispensary, relocated near the medical school, for clinical teaching. The apprenticeship requirement was replaced by clinical teaching courses at the Dispensary. That same year, the Medical Institution of Yale College became the Medical Department of Yale College and obtained a new charter from the State Legislature. In 1880, students began to pay tuition to Yale College which then paid the professors. In this period, physician/professors made the bulk of their income through private practice. By the 1870s, the Medical School was running at a deficit, and was dependent upon the Corporation to make an annual appropriation from general funds.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in two series: 1. Incoming Letters to the Dean or the Yale Administration. 2. Committees and Internal Records.

did.unittitle: Incoming Letters to the Dean or the Yale Administration

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Letters by individuals, organized alphabetically, to the Dean of the medical school, the President of Yale (Jeremiah Day, Theodore Woolsey, Noah Porter), or the Secretary of Yale (Franklin B. Dexter). They include, among other subjects, letters of acceptance for positions on the medical faculty and letters of resignation, and letters from former graduates who still owe tuition debt. Some letters are from medical faculty members, expressing their personal opinions to the Yale administration.

did.unittitle: Abernethy, August H., to Worthington Hooker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Late payment of student debt by a graduate (M.D., 1864).

did.unittitle: American Medical Association Committee on Medical Education

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dr. Thomas asks, on behalf of the committee, for details of the Medical Institution of Yale College: numbers matriculating and graduating; length of course; presence of summer course; if clinical attendance is required; if dissection is required; and if possession of a diploma alone is sufficient for practice.

did.unittitle: Asta-Buruaga, Louis, to George Jarvis Brush

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Encloses a copy of regulations for examination in medicine in the University of Chile and a copy of Diario Official de la Republica de Chile (November 3, 1884) which recognized the Yale M.D. for practice in Chile. Brush was Professor of Metallurgy at Yale College, 1864-1898.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Hennepin County Medical Society, Minnesota, to Lindsley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Secretary, W. F. Hutchinson informs Lindsley that H. H. Leonard filed a diploma from Yale dated 1850, but is now practicing homeopathy in this county "with an openly avowed disbelief" in what he was taught. Lindsley might wish to take action. [H. H. Leonard is not listed in published records as a medical graduate of Yale in 1850.]

did.unittitle: Jackson, James C., Hartford, to Worthington Hooker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Leonard Sanford and Francis Bacon are connected [possibly clinical instruction through Knight Hospital] asked permission to print a circular in the Proceedings of the Connecticut Medical Society. Would the Medical School also want a circular printed? A note by Hooker to Lindsley on the back of the letter asks how to respond.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Having learned of the pecuniary status of the medical school, he assents to Lindsley's proposition [to request funds from the Connecticut Medical Society or its members?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These letters relate to the organization of the Medical Institution of Yale College. Silliman, professor of chemistry at Yale, and a future professor of chemistry in the new medical school at Yale, writes to Knight who is studying medicine in Philadelphia. The Prudential committee has appropriated $200 for Knight to bring back anatomical preparations. .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses the anatomical prepartions desired, including three skeletons. Thinks Kinght has more claim on an appointment in the new school than anyone else.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Silliman tells Knight that he will be appointed to the faculty and gives him advice on preparation for the position. The appointment is to remain secret for now.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Candidacy of Nathan Smith and concern about his "infidelity" in religion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On lectures given by medical faculty for Yale College. Suggests that William Tully be appointed a paid lecturer in botany in Yale College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asks for an annual circular of the Medical Institution of Yale College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Criticism of Lindsey's memorial to the Corporation that Dispensary physicians and clinical teachers be recognized. The object could be better met through the medical school's plan of reorganization.

did.unittitle: Smith, Herbert E., to Franklin B. Dexter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accepts posititon and asks about salary. (Smith becomes professor of chemistry and Dean of the Medical School from 1885 to 1910.)

scopecontent.p: Agrees to continue for another year as "lecturer on insanity."

scopecontent.p: On financial issues including salary of professors, payment of student fees, and money left over for apparatus. Written as a "private estimate" rather than the "official estimate." "Examined and approved by B. Silliman."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Proposes that the school advertise in the Medical Record.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning the misunderstanding by which he did not get a gratuitous course of lectures. (See letters from Charles Carrington, and from Connecticut Medical Society, folder 3).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Young (M.D., 1866) requests an annual circular and asks if he may now take the gratuitous course of lectures he was recommended for in 1862.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Committee to Nominate Professors nominated physicians to the President of Yale and the Yale Corporation to fill vacant chairs in the medical school. For almost all of the period, the Committee was a joint committee of representatives of Yale and the Connecticut Medical Society. Afterwards, the faculty of the Medical Department nominated professors and lecturers.

Charles Hooker, Secretary of Connecticut Medical Society, to Jeremiah Day

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Carmalt, and a chair of clinical surgery for Francis Bacon. Also requests the nomination of two lecturers.

did.unittitle: Committee of Examination: Candidates for M.D., 1819-1829

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folders 18-23 contain letters or reports from the Committee of Examination for the Medical Institution of Yale College to the President and Fellows of Yale College listing those students who passed the examination and should be awarded an M.D. For most of this period, the Committee consisted of members of the Faculty and members of the Connecticut Medical Society. The list for 1822 is missing..

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes on the qualifications of five students and whether they should be accepted and whether fees should be reduced.

did.unittitle: Results of a preliminary examination of candidates for admission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scores on examinations in physics and mathematics and whether the candidates passed. Only 5 of 11 candidates passed both examinations.

did.unittitle: Student petitions to the Dean and Medical Facutly
Class of 1852 to "Gentlemen of the Medical Faculty"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asking for a public event the day after examinations at the end of their studies to commemorate their graduation. The class recommends a valedictorian and a class poet.

did.unittitle: "Statement" of Cornelius Wade Bull to the Medical Faculty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bull (Yale College, 1863, M.D., 1867), a current student from Tallahassee, Florida, requests to take his second course of lectures gratuitously as a county student because of his recent loss of access to property in Florida. He has voted in New Haven.

did.unittitle: "Petition for a course of lectures on Medical Jurisprudence"
Petition "Respecting Public Exercises at the Close of Terms"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Because of the class's "misfortune" in electing a valedictorian, the class petitions to omit the graduation exercises this year and that the medical faculty should in the future name the valedictorian.

did.unittitle: Petition of senior and junior classes to exempt them from the newly required preliminary examination

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 4 items concerning a student prize funded by Dr. Edwin Bentley for the best microscopic specimens on pathology or surgery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leonard J. Sanford and C.A. Lindsley, Report of Committee on Providing Obstetrical Instruction for 1880-1881. The draft report is addressed to "Chairman."

did.unittitle: Letters from the Dean and Medical Faculty to the President of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rev. Theodore Woolsey served as President of Yale College from 1846 to 1871, followed by the Rev. Noah Porter who was President from 1871 to 1886.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Objecting to supposed assumption by the Corporation of appointive power

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the above issue

did.unittitle: Francis Bacon and Moses C. White to Noah Porter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the need for funds to make improvements to the medical school's Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2 items. Statement of amounts advanced by professors for current expenses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On advances made by professors for expenses of the school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the desirability of printing Porter's address on David Paige Smith

did.unittitle: D. A. Cleaveland and Benjamin Silliman to the President and Fellows of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: They were appointed a committee to request a portrait of the late David Paige Smith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vote of the Medical Faculty on changes in tuition to be submitted to the Prudential Committee. The faculty recommends $125 each for the first two years and $75 for the third year.

did.unittitle: Letters from the President of Yale College to the Dean or Medical Faculty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Corporation overrules Knight's and two other professors' objection to the appointment of Stephen Hubbard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requests the Medical Facuilty's opinion on a document (not included) that he received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Dr. Hill's proposal on teaching dental surgery. See folder 5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Dr. Hill's proposal on teaching dental surgery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He has arranged a meeting of the Committee on Nomination of Professors and would like some of the professors to speak on the need for more professorships and "the qualifications of the men you have thought of." Requests a list of medical graduates from last January.

did.unittitle: Letters from the Dean or Medical Faculty to the Secretary of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Franklin Bowditch Dexter was Secretary of Yale College and of the Yale Corporation from 1869 to 1899.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On teaching medical jurisprudence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of appropriation of $1000. Also a copy of this letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Request that the Corporation pay professors annual salaries, and that student fees be paid to the Treasurer of the College.

did.unittitle: Benjamin Silliman, Jr. to Franklin B. Dexter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As President of the Governing Board of the Medical Department, he informs Dexter that Lindsley will perform the duties of the chair of theory and practice of medicine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On requirements for graduation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Carmalt submitting to the Corporation a vote concerning the Keese prize fund.

did.unittitle: Herbert E. Smith to Franklin B. Dexter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Changes in duties of certain professors.

did.unittitle: Letters from the Secretary of Yale College to the Dean

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These letters are Dexter's notices of action taken by the Yale Corporation on financial and other matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Appropriation of $500 from general funds for the benefit of the Medical Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Corporation endorsed the bylaws submitted last June. See folder 32.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Appropriation of $500.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Appropriation of $500 and possible rental of a building for the Dispensary and the building of a chemical laboratory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Appropriation of $500; representatives of Yale appointed to confer with the Connecticut Medical Society concerning amendments to the charter of the Medical Institution. See folder 37.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: New charter of the Medical Department was not approved by the Corporation because of a particular section of the law which gives authority to the Connecticut General Assembly to amend or repeal the charter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Appropriation of $1122 which includes payment of $200 to Moses White for undertaking extra work in obstetrics; lecturers were approved; notice of a statute regarding students dismissed from one department who apply to another.

did.unittitle: Letters from the Dean or Medical Faculty to the Treasurer of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry Coit Kingsley was Treasurer of Yale College from 1862 to 1886.

did.unittitle: Stephen G. Hubbard and Lindsley to Henry C. Kingsley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: They were appointed to be a committee of the Medical Faculty a provide a statement of the resources of the Medical Department, and they request information on interest on investments.

did.unittitle: Letters from the Treasurer of Yale College to the Dean or Medical Faculty
Henry C. Kingsley to Stephen G. Hubbard and Lindsley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lists investments of the Medical College but denies as improper the other information requested.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the legacy from Mrs. Keese for the Keese Prize Fund.

did.unittitle: By-Laws of the Medical Department of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These by-laws on the internal governance of the Medical Department were approved as amended by the Corporation on December 9, 1875.

did.unittitle: Financial Statements and Reports of the Medical Faculty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Statements and reports of the Dean and Medical Faculty to the Prudential Committee or to the President and Fellows of Yale College. These show that the Medical School was operating on a very limited estimated budget (from $2200 to to $5800) and that expenses were greater than annual income. Each year the Medical Faculty, through its Dean, C. A. Lindsley, requested the Corporation to provide funds to make up the difference. At least some of these documents are drafts or copies kept by the Medical School.

did.unittitle: Lindsley to the Prudential Committee of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Financial Statement of the Medical Department. 2 items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed by C. A. Lindsley and M. C. White for the Committee on Expenditures. 2 items.

did.unittitle: Lindsley to the Corporation of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Medical Faculty requests an appropriation to meet current expenses for the year. The Committee on Expenditure has estimated expenses for the ensuing year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Lindsley to the Corporation of Yale College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Detailed report listing the estimates expenses for fiscal year 1879, the actual expenses, and the estimated expenses for financial year 1880. Signed by C. A. Lindsley and M. C. White, "Committee on Expenses."

did.unittitle: "Financial Condition of the Medical Department of Yale College"
"Medical Institution of Yale College, Annual Statement of Finances, with Estimates for the Year from June 1st 1878 to June 1st 1879"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Medical Faculty to the President and Fellows of Yale College, "Report of the Financial Condition of the Medical Department"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed by C. A. Lindsley, M. C. White, and W. H. Carmalt, Financial Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Medical Department requests funds to pay for the lectures by T. Mitchell Prudden and to purchase projection apparatus, a spectroscope, and apparatus to illustrate chemical physics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses the bequest of David Paige Smith of a large collection of surgical instruments. Signed by Moses C. White, C. A. Lindsley, W. H. Carmalt, "Committee of Med. Faculty."

did.unittitle: Medical Faculty to the President and Fellows of Yale College, "Report for the year ending Sept. 1, 1881 with estimates for the year ending Sep 1, 1882"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed Moses C. White, C. A. Lindsley, and W. H. Carmalt, "Committee of Medical Faculty."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 7 items

did.unittitle: Memorials to the President and Corporation concerning the New Haven Dispensary
Medical Faculty to the President and Fellows of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the need to negotiate with the New Haven Dispensary to facilitate clinical instruction in the Medical Department. Resolution of the faculty that the house adjoining the College be leased for the Dispensary. Signed by C. A. Lindsley.

did.unittitle: Petition of members of the medical Faculty to the Corporation of Yale College ("not sent")

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Petititon to formally recognize the teaching of the attending physicians at the Dispensary by appointing them instructors in the Medical Department. Not signed. (See Benjamin Silliman (Jr.) to Lindsley, June 20, 1879, in folder 13.)

did.unittitle: Dissolution of the agreement between Yale and the Connecticut Medical Society
Resolution of the Connecticut Medical Society, S. B. St. John, Secretary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Resolution to cancel the articles of agreement between the Yale Corporation and the Society made in 1810 and any subsequent modifications.

did.unittitle: Report of the Committee appointed on behalf of the President and Fellows of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On dissolving the formal relationship between the Medical College and the Connecticut Medical Society. Signed by Frederick J. Kingsbury and Henry B. Harrison.

did.unittitle: Other Memorials of the Medical Faculty to the Yale Corporation
Jonathan Knight, Memorial of the Medical Faculty on the need for a separate course of lectures on obstetrics and diseases of children
Draft resolution on the admittance of women to the Medical School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In pencil. Would accept women only if they are admitted to the other departments of the University.

did.unittitle: Medical Faculty to the President and Fellows of Yale College, "A Memorial" (draft?)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "A brief statement of the critical condition of the Medical Department," signed by S. G. Hubbard, Francis Bacon, and Benjamin Silliman. Contains a lengthy discussion of why there are not as many graduates as formerly.

did.unittitle: Medical Faculty to the President and Fellows of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Resolution that the Dickerman property adjacent to the Medical College be purchased.

did.unittitle: Medical Faculty to the President and Fellows of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Memorial on the "critical condition" of the Medical Department, the desire to adopt the three-year graded system, and the need to raise an endowment. Cooperation with the Connecticut Medical Society to secure an endowment has been "unproductive of practical results." Signed by Stephen G. Hubbard and Moses C. White, Committee.

did.unittitle: Committee on Expending the Museum Appropriation, Report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed by C. A. Lindsley and M. C. White. Report on how the $500 appropriated should best be spent. Draft.

did.unittitle: Lindsley to the Prudential Committee of Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the "disposal of the shed water from the rear of the College Building."

did.unittitle: Request for funds for an instructor in histology and assistant in chemistry for one year

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pencil draft, unsigned. See Moses C. White to Noah Poter, n.d., folder 14.

did.unittitle: Connecticut General Assembly, May Session, 1866, "An Act in alteration of an Act, entitled "An Act in relation to the Medical Institution of Yale College"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed Act with manuscript annotations for updating.

did.unittitle: Connecticut House Bill No. 95, "An Act to Incorporate the Medical Department of Yale College"
